Article.Abstract: One promising method to prevent vector-borne diseases is through the use of transmission blocking vaccines (TBVs). However, developing several anti-pathogen TBVs may be impractical. In this study, we have identified a conserved candidate carbohydrate target in the midguts of several Arthropod vectors. A screen of the novel GlycoChip glycan array found that the anti-carbohydrate malaria transmission blocking monoclonal antibody (MG96) preferentially recognized D-mannose (alpha) and the type II lactosamine disaccharide. The specificity for D-mannose was confirmed by competition ELISA using alpha-methyl mannoside as inhibitor. Con A, which identifies terminal mannose residues, did not inhibit MG96 reactivity with mosquito midgut lysates, suggesting that Con A has differential recognition of this monosaccharide. However, the jack bean lectin, Jacalin, which recognizes D-mannose (alpha), d-galactose (alpha/beta) and the T antigen, not only displays a similar banding profile to that recognized by MG96 on immunoblot but was also shown to effectively inhibit MG96. Wheat-germ agglutinin, which recognizes N-acetyllactosamine units, only partially inhibited MG96 reactivity. This highlights the contribution of both glycan moieties to the MG96 epitope or glycotope. Enzyme deglycosylation results suggest that MG96 recognizes a mannose alpha1-6 substitution on an O-linked oligosaccharide. Taken together, the data suggest that MG96 recognizes a discontinuous glycotope composed of Manalpha1-6 proximal to Galbeta1-4GlcNAc-alpha-O-R glycans on arthropod vector midguts. As such, these glycotopes may represent potential transmission blocking vaccine targets for a wide range of vector-borne pathogens.
Article.ArticleTitle: Sugar epitopes as potential universal disease transmission blocking targets.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Animals; Antibodies, Monoclonal; Antigens(immunology); Arachnid Vectors(immunology); Carbohydrates(immunology); Dermacentor(immunology); Digestive System(immunology); Epitopes; Female; Malaria; Male; Mannose(immunology); Siphonaptera(immunology); Triatoma(immunology); Tsetse Flies(immunology); Vaccines(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by subcutaneous injection with Aedes aegypti midgut extracts in RIBI adjuvant. A boost was given 21 d after initial immunization and a final boost immunization was given intravenously 14 d after the second boost. Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. The specificity to mosquito midgut was confirmed using Western blot analysis with midgut extracts and extracts of total carcasses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-reactive mAb MG96 reacted with protein from an Anopheles stephensi cell line ASEIV on Western blot.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by subcutaneous injection with Aedes aegypti midgut extracts in RIBI adjuvant. A boost was given 21 d after initial immunization and a final boost immunization was given intravenously 14 d after the second boost. Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. The specificity to mosquito midgut was confirmed using Western blot analysis with midgut extracts and extracts of total carcasses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-reactive mAb MG96 reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Anopheles gambiae on Western blots. MAb MG96 also reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Triatoma pallidipennis and Dermacentor variabilis.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by subcutaneous injection with Aedes aegypti midgut extracts in RIBI adjuvant. AssayInformation.AssayComments: The mAb MG96 exhibited statistically significant binding to the epitope analyzed against a glycan array of 46 mono- and oligosaccharides.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by subcutaneous injection with Aedes aegypti midgut extracts in RIBI adjuvant. A boost was given 21 d after initial immunization and a final boost immunization was given intravenously 14 d after the second boost. Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. The specificity to mosquito midgut was confirmed using Western blot analysis with midgut extracts and extracts of total carcasses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-reactive mAb MG96 reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Anopheles gambiae on Western blots. MAb MG96 also reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Triatoma pallidipennis and Dermacentor variabilis.

A boost was given 21 d after initial immunization and a final boost immunization was given intravenously 14 d after the second boost. Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. The specificity to mosquito midgut was confirmed using Western blot analysis with midgut extracts and extracts of total carcasses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-reactive mAb MG96 reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from blood-fed female Ctenocephalides felis on Western blots.

Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope-reactive mAb MG96 reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Anopheles gambiae on Western blots. MAb MG96 also reacted with proteins from midgut lysates from Triatoma pallidipennis and Dermacentor variabilis.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized by subcutaneous injection with Aedes aegypti midgut extracts in RIBI adjuvant. A boost was given 21 d after initial immunization and a final boost immunization was given intravenously 14 d after the second boost. Spleens were harvested to generate hybridomas that were screened for midgut specific antibodies by IFA using paraformaldehyde fixed, Triton X-100 permeabilized Ae. aegypti midgut sections. The specificity to mosquito midgut was confirmed using Western blot analysis with midgut extracts and extracts of total carcasses.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope inhibited the binding of mAb MG96 to Anopheles stephensi midgut lysates coated on plates. The monosaccharides D-glucose, D-galactose, or L-arabinose did not inhibit mAb MG96 binding.
